intro: Xanthophyllum pseudoadenotus, commonly known as the golden-flowered mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that belongs to the family Loranthaceae. It typically grows on the branches of host trees, drawing water and nutrients from them while performing photosynthesis with its own chlorophyll. The plant is characterized by its yellowish-green leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers that are often clustered in dense inflorescences. Its seeds are dispersed by birds that consume the fleshy, red berries. Xanthophyllum pseudoadenotus plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat, influencing both the host trees and the bird populations that rely on it for food.
